definition: Easy to raise an army of one thousand, but hard to find a good general. (idiom)
pinyin: qian1 jun1 yi4 de2 , yi1 jiang4 nan2 qiu2

definition: see 鞦韆|秋千[qiu1 qian1]
thousand
(bound form) army/military
easy/amiable/to change/to exchange/prefix corresponding to the English adjective suffix "-able" or "-ible"
surname Yi/abbr. for 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1], the Book of Changes
to obtain/to get/to gain/to catch (a disease)/proper/suitable/proud/contented/to allow/to permit/ready/finished
structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc
to have to/must/ought to/to need to
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
to desire/to invite/to request
will/shall/to use/to take/to checkmate/just a short while ago/(introduces object of main verb, used in the same way as 把[ba3])
general/commander-in-chief (military)/king (chess piece)/to command/to lead
difficult (to...)/problem/difficulty/difficult/not good
disaster/distress/to scold
to seek/to look for/to request/to demand/to beseech
there are no poor soldiers under a good general (idiom)
pinyin: qiang2 jiang4 shou3 xia4 wu2 ruo4 bing1

definition: talented field commander (military)
a fine bird chooses a tree to nest in (proverb)/fig. a talented person chooses a patron of integrity
pinyin: liang2 qin2 ze2 mu4 er2 qi1

definition: expert at appointing people according to their abilities (idiom)/to put the right people in the right places
mediocrity
to lead military operations with extraordinary skill
variant of 人才[ren2 cai2]
lit. Train an army for a thousand days to use it for an hour. (idiom); fig. extensive preparation eventually pays off
pinyin: yang3 bing1 qian1 ri4 , yong4 bing1 yi1 shi2

definition: strategic experts as thick as rain (idiom); no shortage of advisers on strategy
Only an outstanding talent can recognize current trends (idiom). A wise man submits to circumstances.
pinyin: shi2 shi2 wu4 zhe3 wei4 jun4 jie2

definition: lit. to dispatch a general is not as effective as to excite a general/fig. inciting people to action is more effective than dispatching orders
pinyin: qing3 jiang4 bu4 ru2 ji1 jiang4

definition: The cleverest housewife cannot cook without rice (idiom); You won't get anywhere without equipment.
pinyin: qiao3 fu4 nan2 wei2 wu2 mi3 zhi1 chui1

definition: the storm put strong grass to the test (idiom); fig. troubled times test a faithful minister/to show one's true colors after a stern test/also written 疾風勁草|疾风劲草
to appoint people according to their merits (idiom); appointment on the basis of ability and integrity

lit. raised up by Xiao He, cast down by Xiao He (idiom), alluding to Han Xin 韓信|韩信[Han2 Xin4] being made Grand General 大將軍|大将军[da4 jiang1 jun1]/fig. a situation where one's success and failure are both due to the same factor
pinyin: cheng2 ye3 Xiao1 He2 , bai4 ye3 Xiao1 He2

definition: before the troops move, fodder and provisions go first (idiom); logistics comes before military maneuvers/an army marches on its stomach
pinyin: bing1 ma3 wei4 dong4 , liang2 cao3 xian1 xing2
